articles.headline: Miami’s Condo Market Rebounds, Stoking a Building Boom
articles.snippet: As home prices recover and demand for safe investments by foreign investors rises, Miami is booming again with 25 condo projects.
articles.abstract: As home prices recover and demand for safe investments by foreign investors rises, Miami is booming again with 25 condo projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Of the 22,000 condos created in downtown Miami during the boom years, only about 600 remain unsold — thanks mainly to an influx of Latin American investors seeking a safe haven for their money.

articles.headline: Chinese Way of Doing Business: In Cash We Trust
articles.snippet: For all China’s modern trappings, many experts say mutual wariness between the government and its citizens means the country still prefers to pay for things the old-fashioned way.
articles.abstract: For all China’s modern trappings, many experts say mutual wariness between the government and its citizens means the country still prefers to pay for things the old-fashioned way.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Lin Lu remembers the day last December when a Chinese businessman showed up at the car dealership he works for in north China and paid for a new BMW 5 Series Gran Turismo — entirely in cash.

articles.headline: Banks Rally Against Strict Controls of Foreign Bets
articles.snippet: Wall Street bankers and foreign finance ministers are waging a campaign to block American financial regulators from extending their policing powers far beyond the nation’s shores.
articles.abstract: Wall Street bankers and foreign finance ministers are waging a campaign to block American financial regulators from extending their policing powers far beyond the nation’s shores.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Wall Street bankers and some of the world’s top finance ministers are waging a bitter international campaign to block Washington financial regulators from extending their policing powers far beyond the nation’s shores.

articles.headline: The Most Hated Bangladeshi, Toppled From a Shady Empire
articles.snippet: Sohel Rana is under arrest after the collapse of his factory building last week left nearly 400 people dead, but until now he has been a powerful figure, trailed by his own biker gang.
articles.abstract: Sohel Rana is under arrest after the collapse of his factory building last week left nearly 400 people dead, but until now he has been a powerful figure, trailed by his own biker gang.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVAR, Bangladesh — Barely 20 miles from the national capital, this gritty suburb is now a dusty, chaotic industrial center littered with factories that produce clothes for leading Western brands. Building codes are often unenforced, regulatory oversight is flimsy and the men wielding power often travel with armed guards.

articles.headline: After Boston Attack, 3 Friends Covered It Up, Prosecutors Say
articles.snippet: Affidavits portray a scene of confusion as three young men, stunned to realize their friend Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was being sought as a terrorist, debated whether to help him.
articles.abstract: Affidavits portray a scene of confusion as three young men, stunned to realize their friend Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was being sought as a terrorist, debated whether to help him.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were perhaps Dzhokhar Tsarnaev’s closest friends during his two years at college, an American classmate from high school and two Russian-speaking students from Kazakhstan. The Kazakhs seemingly had money and drove expensive cars. They entertained Mr. Tsarnaev at their off-campus apartment, and he partied with them in New York. One of them lent Mr. Tsarnaev a black BMW after he smashed his Honda Civic in an accident.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Katharine Q. Seelye
